p: Influenza data for Norway were obtained from the Norwegian sentinel surveillance system (Norwegian Institute of Public Health) and contain weekly reports of influenza-like illness (ILI) cases for 16 consecutive influenza seasons, from 1998â€“2014. Such sentinel data have been shown to provide reliable estimates of influenza activity across Norway and the wider European region [ 17]. ILI cases are diagnosed by 201 general practitioner (GP) offices across Norway according to the International Classification of Primary Care (ICPC) code R80. GPs are required by law to submit weekly reports, and are spatially distributed according to geographic location, population size, and reporting frequency [ 18, 19]. Each office is identified by a unique 6-digit code that indicates the municipality and county in which it is located. Overall, the surveillance system represents approximately 16% of the Norwegian population and is assumed to be geographically representative [ 19].
